nodes.title: Stack Reconciler Era (2013-2016)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"files":["packages/react-reconciler/"],"prompt":"## Stack Reconciler Era (2013-2016)

### Overview
The "Stack Reconciler" was React's original reconciliation algorithm, in use from React's initial release (May 2013) until React 16 (September 2017).

### Why "Stack"?
The name comes from its use of the **JavaScript call stack** for traversing the component tree:
- Recursive function calls descended into children
- The JS engine's call stack tracked the traversal position
- Reconciliation was inherently **synchronous** and **blocking**

### Location in Codebase
Before the Fiber rewrite, the reconciler lived in:
```
src/renderers/shared/stack/reconciler/
```

Key files included:
- `ReactReconciler.js`
- `ReactCompositeComponent.js`
- `ReactMultiChild.js`
- `ReactChildReconciler.js`

### Stack Reconciler Removal
The Stack Reconciler was gradually removed in React 16.x:

**PR #10794** - "Remove Stack (part 1, safe: unused files and tests)"
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/10794
October 17, 2017

**PR #10511** - "Delete ReactNativeStack"
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/10511
August 25, 2017

**PR #8415** - "[WIP] Delete Stack Reconciler" (Sebastian's tracking PR)
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/8415
November 24, 2016

### Historical Significance
The Stack Reconciler served React well for 4+ years and billions of renders. Its limitations around responsiveness and prioritization drove the need for Fiber, but its fundamental reconciliation algorithm (the "diffing" logic documented at facebook.github.io/react/docs/reconciliation.html) remained largely unchanged in Fiber.

### Reference
Dan Abramov recommended understanding the Stack Reconciler by stepping through it with a debugger:
https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/699395627264962561"}

nodes.title: Stack Reconciler was React's original synchronous recursive reconciliation algorithm
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## Stack Reconciler: Original Architecture

The Stack Reconciler was React's original reconciliation algorithm from 2013-2017.

### Key Characteristic
It used the JavaScript call stack recursively to traverse and reconcile the component tree. This meant:
- Reconciliation was **synchronous** - once started, it had to complete
- The main thread was blocked during the entire process
- No way to pause, abort, or prioritize work

### Historical Context
Dan Abramov described understanding the Stack Reconciler in this tweet (referenced in Issue #6170):
https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/699395627264962561

> "I found this method really useful to understand how reconciliation works today"
> — Dan Abramov, March 18, 2016

### Source
Issue #6170 comment by @gaearon:
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/6170#issuecomment-198434184

### Files
The Stack Reconciler lived in `src/renderers/shared/stack/reconciler/` before being removed."}

nodes.title: Stack Reconciler limitation: Could not pause work mid-tree - once started, must complete entire reconciliation synchronously
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## Stack Reconciler Limitation: Synchronous/Blocking Nature

### The Core Problem
From Issue #6170 "New Core Algorithm" (March 2, 2016):
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/6170

Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage) opened this issue stating the need for:

> "Incremental updates in chunks. Maybe even two different versions of the same tree at the same time!"

### Why This Mattered
The Stack Reconciler used recursive function calls on the JS call stack. From Issue #7942:
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/7942

Sebastian Markbåge explained (October 20, 2016):

> "Why does it need to be this complicated? We can use the normal JS stack for this but any time we yield in a `requestIdleCallback` we would have to rebuild the stack when we continue. Since this only lasts for about 50ms when idle, we would spend some time unwinding and rebuilding the stack each time."

### Impact
- Large component trees caused "jank" (dropped frames)
- User interactions felt sluggish on complex UIs
- No way to prioritize urgent updates (like typing) over less urgent ones (like data fetching)

### Timeline
- Problem identified: Pre-2016
- Solution work began: March 2, 2016 (Issue #6170)
- Solution shipped: September 26, 2017 (React 16.0.0)"}

nodes.title: Stack Reconciler limitation: Used JS call stack recursively - meant updates blocked main thread, causing jank on complex trees
Stack Reconciler limitation: Could not prioritize different types of updates (user input vs data fetching)
Fiber Architecture Era (2016-2017)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## Fiber Architecture Era (2016-2017)

### The Announcement: Issue #6170 "New Core Algorithm"
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/6170

### Author
Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)

### Timeline
- Opened: March 2, 2016
- Closed: July 26, 2017 (with React 16 Beta 1)

### Original Issue Body (verbatim)
> "I'm just going to start this as a thread to give everyone notice of work being put into the core reconciliation algorithm.
>
> This will need to include features like:
> - Incremental updates in chunks. Maybe even two different versions of the same tree at the same time!
> - Back and forth yielding (and prerender) to support layout. This probably also includes a new type of 'context'.
> - Error boundaries that catches updates.
> - Make this work with existing tooling such as dev tools, perf tools, server rendering, various renderers.
>
> If you're working on fixing issues with life-cycles or the core reconciliation parts (like child reconciliation) then you might want to be aware that this is a moving target. There might be requests for changes unrelated to the status quo but related to this future work. It might require a lot of context and commitment to be able to contribute to these parts."

### Key Milestone Comments

**March 2, 2016** - @jimfb:
> "Perhaps ironically, that page [reconciliation docs] is one of the few things that probably won't change. It's just the details of the implementation (specifically with regards to the flow of control) that will change; the high-level description remains the same."

**May 5, 2016** - @gaearon:
> "Some initial work started here: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/6690"

**October 31, 2016** - @gaearon shared tracking resources:
> "Related:
> - How is Fiber codebase different? https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/7942
> - What is left to do in Fiber? https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/7925
> - Is Fiber ready yet? http://isfiberreadyyet.com"

**July 26, 2017** - @gaearon closing the issue:
> "I think we did it? React 16 Beta 1 ships with the new algorithm.
> https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/10294
> This is not the end but a beginning of a new chapter for React.
> The basics of all these things are now in place (even though some are not exposed yet), and I'm excited to see how they will evolve over time."

### Duration
**16 months** from announcement to React 16 Beta 1
**18 months** from announcement to React 16.0.0 stable (September 26, 2017)

### Key Related Issues
- #7942 - Fiber Principles (design rationale)
- #7925 - Fiber Umbrella (implementation tracking)
- #10294 - React 16 Beta announcement"}

nodes.title: How to achieve incremental/interruptible rendering in JavaScript?
Option: Use Web Workers/threads for parallelism
Option: Use JavaScript generator functions for yielding
Option: Use OCaml algebraic effects (BuckleScript)
Option: Custom Fiber data structure with cooperative scheduling (CHOSEN)
REJECTED threads: JS lacks good thread support; can't safely abort thread mid-work; can't share memoized work between threads; ecosystem not ready
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## REJECTED: Web Workers/Threads for Parallelism

### Source
Issue #7942 "Fiber Principles: Contributing To Fiber"
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/7942#issuecomment-254984862

### Author
Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)
Date: October 20, 2016

### Full Quote

> "**Aren't you just working around the lack of threads in the language?**
>
> Yes and no.
>
> It is true that we don't have a good option in JavaScript to run threads - and that is a huge problem. We tried exploring various options of running in Web Workers, parallel JS, tried to propose shared immutable persistent data structures to the language, experimented with custom VM tweaks etc. JavaScript the language isn't very suitable for this because of mutable shared runtimes like prototypes. The ecosystem isn't ready for it because you have to duplicate code loading and module initialization across workers. Garbage collectors are not as efficient as they currently are if they have to be thread safe, and VM implementors seem to be unwilling to bare the implementation cost of persistent data structures. Shared mutable typed arrays seems to be moving along but requiring all data to go through this layer seems to be unfeasible in the ecosystem today. Artificial boundaries between different parts of the code base also doesn't work very well and introduces unnecessary friction. Even then you have lots of JS code like utility libraries that have to be duplicated across workers. Which leads to slower start up time and memory overhead. So, yes, threads are likely out of the question until we can target something like Web Assembly.
>
> **However**, an interesting realization is that there are _other_ benefits of the Fiber architecture that are applicable whether you have threads or not.
>
> You can't safely abort the background thread. Aborting and restarting a thread is not very cheap. In many languages it is also not safe because you could be in the middle of some lazy initialization work. Even though it is effectively interrupted, you have to continue spending CPU cycles on it."

### Key Reasons for Rejection
1. JS lacks good thread support due to mutable shared runtimes
2. Code duplication across workers (slower startup, memory overhead)
3. Can't safely abort a thread mid-work
4. Can't share memoized work between threads
5. Even with threads, still need yield points for safe abortion

### Interesting Insight
Sebastian noted that even ComponentKit (native iOS) which HAS threads still needs cooperative scheduling - threads alone don't solve the problem."}

nodes.title: REJECTED generators: Stateful - can't resume in middle; syntactic overhead wrapping every function; can't skip ahead to reuse memoized work from earlier steps
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## REJECTED: JavaScript Generator Functions

### Source
Issue #7942 "Fiber Principles: Contributing To Fiber"
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/7942#issuecomment-254987818

### Author
Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)
Date: October 20, 2016

### Full Quote

> "**Couldn't you just use generator functions like other scheduling frameworks have done?**
>
> No.
>
> There's two reasons for this.
>
> 1) Generators doesn't just let you yield in the middle of a stack. You have to wrap every single function in a generator. This not only adds a lot of syntactic overhead but also runtime overhead in any existing implementation. It's fair that the syntax might be more helpful than not, but the perf issue still stands.
>
> 2) The biggest reason, however, is that generators are stateful. You can't resume in the middle of it.
>
> ```js
> function* doWork(a, b, c) {
>   var x = doExpensiveWorkA(a);
>   yield;
>   var y = x + doExpensiveWorkB(b);
>   yield;
>   var z = y + doExpensiveWorkC(c);
>   return z;
> }
> ```
>
> If I want to execute this across multiple time slices I can just step through this. However, if I get an update to B when I have already completed `doExpensiveWorkA(a)` _and_ `doExpensiveWorkB(b)` but not `doExpensiveWorkC(c)` there is no way for me to reuse the value `x`. I.e. to skip ahead to `doExpensiveWorkB` with a different value for `b` but still reuse the result of `doExpensiveWorkA(a)`.
>
> This is important to React since we do a lot of memoization."

### Key Reasons for Rejection
1. **Syntactic overhead**: Every function must be wrapped as a generator
2. **Runtime overhead**: Performance cost in existing JS implementations  
3. **Stateful nature**: Can't resume from arbitrary points
4. **Memoization incompatible**: Can't skip ahead while reusing earlier work
5. React's memoization strategy requires ability to partially reuse work

### The Memoization Problem Explained
React needs to be able to say "props for component A didn't change, skip re-rendering A but continue with B". Generators can't do this - they're linear state machines."}

nodes.title: REJECTED OCaml effects: Non-trivial overhead in JS compilation; would need to clone each fiber to resume; lots of nested handlers add overhead
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## REJECTED: OCaml Algebraic Effects (BuckleScript)

### Source
Issue #7942 "Fiber Principles: Contributing To Fiber"
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/7942#issuecomment-254989361

### Author
Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)
Date: October 20, 2016

### Full Quote

> "**Ok, but what about OCaml's algebraic effects then? BuckleScript can compile them.**
>
> There is some non-trivial overhead in the JS version but assuming that would be ok.
>
> To use algebraic effects in OCaml in this way, I think we would need to clone each fiber so that we can resume it. It is possible that a compiler could reuse an immutable stack frame / fiber without copying but that's not how it works now. Without that, we only get limited benefits.
>
> We would also end up with lots of nested handlers which would add to the overhead and also add linear search time to find the top handler when we do yield.
>
> Besides, to support the existing React API we need a set of features that overlap with the implementation of fibers, such as 'return pointers' so by combining them we get some benefits.
>
> I do have high hopes that one day we can just use effects for our use cases internally, but we could also use it to make an even simpler React API itself. However, for now, I think that it is probably easier to have lower level control even though the complexity is higher.
>
> I do look forward to seeing other implementations that prioritize implementation simplicity or using complex compilers to solve the same problems."

### Key Reasons for Rejection
1. **Non-trivial JS overhead** when compiled from OCaml
2. **Cloning required** to resume fibers - no reuse
3. **Nested handlers overhead** + linear search time
4. Already need fiber-like structures for React API anyway

### Future Hope
Sebastian noted algebraic effects might be viable in the future for a simpler React API, but not practical in 2016."}

nodes.title: CHOSEN Fiber: Fixed data structure with singly-linked list traversal; no JS stack recursion; enables yielding at any point; supports memoization; allows priority scheduling
PR #6690: New Reconciler Infra - Initial Fiber infrastructure (May 2016)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## PR #6690: New Reconciler Infra - Initial Fiber Infrastructure

### URL
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/6690

### Author
Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)

### Timeline
- Created: May 3, 2016
- Merged: May 11, 2016

### PR Description (verbatim)
> "This is an outline for the new reconciler infrastructure.
>
> I created a noop renderer to have something to get started from.
>
> I split the reconciler folder into old and new, as well as shared. I put shouldUpdateReactComponent in shared as an example of a utility that can easily be shared between both. I plan on breaking out more utilities like these.
>
> Builds on top of #6682"

### Significance
This was the **FIRST** PR that laid the groundwork for Fiber. It:
1. Created the initial directory structure for the new reconciler
2. Split reconciler into `old/` (Stack) and `new/` (Fiber) folders
3. Created a noop renderer as a starting template
4. Established the pattern of shared utilities between reconcilers

### Context
This PR came 2 months after Issue #6170 "New Core Algorithm" was opened (March 2, 2016), representing the transition from design discussions to actual implementation.

### Files Changed
- Created `src/renderers/shared/fiber/` directory structure
- Created initial `ReactFiber.js`, `ReactFiberReconciler.js`"}

nodes.title: PR #7034: Host Container Fiber and Priority Levels (June 2016)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## PR #7034: Host Container Fiber and Priority Levels

### URL
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/7034

### Author
Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)

### Timeline
- Created: June 14, 2016
- Merged: June 30, 2016

### PR Description (verbatim)
> "Basically I'm working on the top level nodes. I use a fiber for that. That's nice because it allow us to nest them inside the tree for things like portals. It also allows me to reuse the child reconciliation for the top level.
>
> The current thing won't quite work because there needs to be two fibers even at the top level. Work in progress. I might just to another mutable top level node that's not a fiber.
>
> It also has a priority feature which searches the **current** tree (not the work in progress since that no long exists after a flush) for the highest priority work to do next. This is a key component of this architecture. The priority flag represents the highest priority in the subtree.
>
> Pending state updates will have priority associated with themselves on the fiber itself.
>
> There is currently no priority associated with the pending props themselves which means that they get the same priority as anything deep in the tree. Pending props is kind of an edge case. I think that the only time that happens is if you have a high priority update which leads to update a lower priority tree so that the update in that tree gets deprioritized. But I'm not completely sure how this will work yet. Maybe they should only ever exists on the 'work in progress' nodes.
>
> When a new change comes in we reset and rescan the tree. That change could've been a higher priority or higher/earlier in the tree than what we're currently working on. We can probably avoid this reset+rescan for new changes which has lower priority.
>
> Currently this reset throws out the work already done to the tree, so we'll need to start look at the 'alternate' tree to see if there was already any work done there that we can reuse. We can use pending props for that."

### Key Concepts Introduced
1. **Host Container Fiber**: Top-level fiber for the root container
2. **Priority System**: Priority flags to schedule different types of work
3. **Work-in-Progress / Current tree duality**: The "alternate" tree pattern
4. **Priority scanning**: Finding highest priority work in subtree

### Significance
This PR introduced the **priority scheduling** concept that would later evolve into:
- React 16's basic scheduling
- React 18's lanes system
- The foundation for Concurrent Mode"}

nodes.title: PR #6859: Child Reconciler + New Coroutines Primitive (May 2016)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## PR #6859: Child Reconciler + New Coroutines Primitive

### URL
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/6859

### Author
Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)

### Timeline
- Created: May 24, 2016
- Merged: May 27, 2016

### PR Description (verbatim)
> "First commit is expanding the structure of child reconciliation. The steps are organized around phase rather than type of component. I found this helpful for now but I'm sure other structures make sense too.
>
> New Coroutine Primitive. Alternative APIs are possible. The important part is getting the implementation details right to have all the pieces available in the reconciler."

### Significance
This PR introduced:
1. **Child Reconciliation Algorithm**: The diffing logic for Fiber children
2. **Phase-based organization**: Work organized by phase (beginWork, completeWork) rather than component type
3. **Coroutines Primitive**: Early exploration of async patterns (later evolved into Suspense concepts)

### Context
This was the 3rd major Fiber PR, coming just 2 weeks after #6690. The rapid cadence shows the intense development period in May 2016.

### Historical Note
The "Coroutines Primitive" mentioned here was an early experiment that explored yielding control. While coroutines as an API didn't ship, the underlying ideas influenced later features like Suspense."}

nodes.title: PR #10758: React Reconciler Package - Created npm package (Sept 2017)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"## PR #10758: React Reconciler Package - Created npm Package

### URL
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/10758

### Author
Dustan Kasten (@iamdustan)

### Timeline
- Created: September 20, 2017
- Merged: October 11, 2017
- 6 days before React 16.0.0 release (September 26, 2017)

### PR Description (verbatim)
> "Alternative approach to #10641. Rather than create the entire packaging and bundling script this exposes the React Reconciler as a factory package so all private+global state is unique per reconciler which solves the original concerns raised by @gaearon in https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/9103#issuecomment-319750290.
>
> I think it also solves the open question *How should we handle React-specific stuff* pretty well since it doesn't change the current rollup/build script at this point."

### Why This Mattered
This PR created `react-reconciler` as a **standalone npm package**, enabling:
1. **Custom Renderers**: Anyone could build their own React renderer (like react-three-fiber, react-pdf, ink)
2. **Renderer Independence**: Each reconciler instance has unique private/global state
3. **Ecosystem Growth**: Opened the door to the custom renderer ecosystem

### Key Design Decision
The reconciler is exposed as a **factory function** rather than a singleton:
```js
const Reconciler = require('react-reconciler');
const MyRenderer = Reconciler(hostConfig);
```

This ensures each renderer has isolated state, preventing conflicts when multiple renderers exist in one app.

### Related Issues
- #10641 - Earlier (rejected) approach
- #9103 - Original discussion about exposing reconciler

### Impact
This PR enabled projects like:
- `react-three-fiber` (3D graphics)
- `ink` (terminal UIs)
- `react-pdf` (PDF generation)
- `react-native` (uses its own reconciler build)
- `react-hardware` (IoT devices)"}

nodes.title: React 16.0.0 Released - Fiber Ships to Production (Sept 26, 2017)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":100,"prompt":"## React 16.0.0 Released - Fiber Ships to Production

### Release Date
September 26, 2017

### Announcement Issue
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/10294 "React 16 Beta"

### Key Quote from @gaearon (July 26, 2017)
Issue #6170 closing comment:
> "I think we did it? React 16 Beta 1 ships with the new algorithm.
> https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/10294
> This is not the end but a beginning of a new chapter for React.
> The basics of all these things are now in place (even though some are not exposed yet), and I'm excited to see how they will evolve over time."

### What React 16 Shipped With (from Issue #10294)

> "React 16 is the first release that ships with a rewrite of the React core (previously codenamed "Fiber"). This rewrite had a few goals:
>
> - Remove old internal abstractions that didn't age well and hindered internal changes.
> - Let us ship some of the most requested features like returning arrays from render, recovering from component errors, and readable component stack traces for every error.
> - Enable us to start experimenting with asynchronous rendering of components for better perceived performance.
>
> **This initial React 16.0 release is mostly focused on compatibility with existing apps. It does not enable asynchronous rendering yet.** We will introduce an opt-in to the async mode later during React 16.x."

### Breaking Changes in React 16.0

**Error Handling:**
> "Previously, runtime errors used to put React into a broken state and produce cryptic errors. React 16 fixes this by introducing a special kind of components called 'error boundaries'. Error boundaries can catch runtime errors in a component tree, log them, and display a fallback UI instead."

> "If there is an uncaught error in a component, and there is no error boundary up in the tree, **the whole component tree will be unmounted**."

**Lifecycle Changes:**
> "When replacing `<A />` with `<B />`, `B.componentWillMount` now always happens before `A.componentWillUnmount`. Previously, `A.componentWillUnmount` could fire first in some cases."

**Packaging:**
> "There is no `react/lib/*` and `react-dom/lib/*` anymore. Even in CommonJS environments, React and ReactDOM are precompiled to single files ('flat bundles')."

### New Features Enabled by Fiber

1. **Error Boundaries** (`componentDidCatch`)
2. **Return arrays from render** (Fragments)
3. **Return strings from render**
4. **Portals** (`ReactDOM.createPortal()`)
5. **Streaming server rendering** (`ReactDOMServer.renderToNodeStream()`)
6. **Custom DOM attributes** (pass through unknown attributes)

### Timeline from Fiber Start to Release
- March 2, 2016: Issue #6170 opened
- May 3, 2016: First Fiber PR merged (#6690)
- July 26, 2017: React 16 Beta 1
- September 26, 2017: React 16.0.0 stable

**Total development time: ~18 months**

### What Was NOT Shipped Yet
Async rendering was not enabled in 16.0 - this would come later:
- React 16.3: `getDerivedStateFromProps`, new context API
- React 16.6: `React.lazy`, `Suspense` (code splitting only)
- React 18: Full concurrent features

### Related Links
- Blog post: https://reactjs.org/blog/2017/09/26/react-v16.0.html
- Error handling blog: https://facebook.github.io/react/blog/2017/07/26/error-handling-in-react-16.html"}

nodes.title: React 16.3 Era - Async Rendering Preparation (March 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"React 16.3.0 released March 29, 2018.

This release focused on preparing React for async rendering by:
1. New Context API (PR #11818) - propagates updates even when shouldComponentUpdate returns false
2. React.forwardRef (PR #12346) - enables forwarding refs through HOCs
3. React.createRef (PR #12162) - ergonomic alternative to callback refs
4. getDerivedStateFromProps lifecycle (PR #12028) - safer replacement for componentWillReceiveProps
5. getSnapshotBeforeUpdate lifecycle (PR #12404) - read DOM before mutations
6. React.StrictMode (PR #12083) - helps prepare apps for async rendering

CHANGELOG PR: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/12488
Merged: March 29, 2018
Author: Dan Abramov (@gaearon)

The release introduced React.StrictMode specifically to help developers find unsafe lifecycle usage that would break with async rendering."}

nodes.title: PR #11818: New Context API (Dec 2017 - Jan 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #11818: New Context API
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/11818
Author: Andrew Clark (@acdlite)
Created: December 9, 2017
Merged: January 25, 2018

From PR description:
"Introduces a declarative context API that propagates updates even when shouldComponentUpdate returns false."

WHY this was needed:
- Old context API was "legacy" and had shouldComponentUpdate bailout problem
- Updates to context would be blocked by intermediate components returning false from shouldComponentUpdate
- This broke libraries like React Redux that relied on context for store propagation

RFC: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/2

Key implementation details from PR:
- "Should be able to stop scanning when we hit a matching provider, then continue the scan later"
- Uses Object.is for comparing context values (not === or shallowEqual)
- "Unwind context stack when interrupted (error, high pri update)"

The new API used React.createContext() to create Provider/Consumer pairs that work correctly with Fiber's interruptible rendering."}

nodes.title: PR #12346: React.forwardRef Implementation (March 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #12346: RFC #30: React.forwardRef implementation
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/12346
Author: Brian Vaughn (@bvaughn)
Created: March 8, 2018
Merged: March 14, 2018

From PR description:
"Add new API, React.forwardRef, implemented as a new element type."

WHY this was needed:
- HOCs (Higher-Order Components) wrap components, breaking ref forwarding
- With refs, you'd get the wrapper component's ref, not the inner component
- This was a major pain point for library authors (e.g., React Redux connect())
- Needed a way to "forward" refs through wrapper components to the inner component

RFC: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/30

Usage pattern from PR:
```js
return React.forwardRef((props, ref) => (
  <ThemeContextInjector {...props} forwardedRef={ref} />
));
```

This enabled ref forwarding through HOCs while maintaining the new context API's patterns."}

nodes.title: PR #12083: React.StrictMode for Async Rendering Preparation
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #12083: Opt into unsafe lifecycle warnings without async tree
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/12083
Author: Brian Vaughn (@bvaughn)
Created: January 23, 2018
Merged: January 25, 2018

From PR description:
"Opts a subtree into the same warnings as AsyncComponent does, but does not actually enable async rendering. This same mechanism could be extended for similar warnings in the future (eg compiler, React Fabric)."

WHY this was critical:
- Async rendering (later called Concurrent Mode) would break certain lifecycle patterns
- componentWillMount, componentWillReceiveProps, componentWillUpdate could be called multiple times
- Libraries and apps needed a way to find these issues BEFORE async rendering was enabled
- StrictMode warns about:
  - Unsafe lifecycle usage
  - Legacy string ref API usage
  - Deprecated findDOMNode usage
  - Legacy context API usage
  - Unexpected side effects (double-invokes render/lifecycle in dev)

This was the first step in the multi-year migration path toward Concurrent React."}

nodes.title: React 16.3 deprecated unsafe lifecycles: componentWillMount, componentWillReceiveProps, componentWillUpdate
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"React 16.3 deprecated "unsafe" lifecycles with UNSAFE_ prefix:
- componentWillMount -> UNSAFE_componentWillMount
- componentWillReceiveProps -> UNSAFE_componentWillReceiveProps  
- componentWillUpdate -> UNSAFE_componentWillUpdate

PR #12028 added getDerivedStateFromProps as replacement
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/12028
Author: Brian Vaughn (@bvaughn)

WHY these were "unsafe" for async rendering:
1. These lifecycles run during the "render phase" (before commit)
2. In async rendering, render phase can be interrupted and restarted
3. This means these lifecycles could be called MULTIPLE TIMES for a single update
4. Side effects in these methods (fetching data, subscriptions, DOM mutations) would be duplicated
5. The "will" prefix implied they run once before something - but async breaks that contract

The replacements (getDerivedStateFromProps, getSnapshotBeforeUpdate) are:
- Static methods (no access to `this`) - prevents side effects
- OR run in commit phase (getSnapshotBeforeUpdate) - guaranteed to run once

This was essential preparation for Concurrent Mode."}

nodes.title: React 16.6 Era - Suspense Ships (Oct 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"React 16.6.0 released October 23, 2018

CHANGELOG PR: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/13927
Author: Dan Abramov (@gaearon)

Major reconciler-related features:
1. Suspense shipped (stable for code-splitting) - renamed from unstable_Placeholder
2. React.lazy() for code splitting components
3. React.memo() as PureComponent for functions
4. static contextType for easier context consumption in classes
5. getDerivedStateFromError lifecycle
6. Scheduler package created (experimental)

Key renames in this release:
- unstable_AsyncMode -> unstable_ConcurrentMode
- unstable_Placeholder -> Suspense
- delayMs -> maxDuration
- React.pure() -> React.memo()

This release marked the first PUBLIC shipping of Suspense for production use (code-splitting only).
Data fetching Suspense was NOT yet ready."}

nodes.title: PR #12279: Suspense - Core Implementation (Feb-May 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #12279: Suspense
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/12279
Author: Andrew Clark (@acdlite)
Created: February 24, 2018
Merged: May 11, 2018

From PR description:
The PR body contained a GIF demonstrating the feature and a TODO list.

WHY Suspense was needed:
- Before: Code splitting required manual loading state management
- Components had to manage their own "loading" states
- No way to "wait" for async data at the component level
- Wanted declarative async handling like try/catch but for loading states

Key implementation details:
- Components can "throw" a Promise to indicate they're loading
- Parent Suspense boundary catches thrown promises
- Shows fallback UI while waiting for promises to resolve
- "Hide timed-out children instead of deleting them so their state is preserved" (PR #13823)

Development timeline:
- Feb 24, 2018: PR created
- April 13: Rebased on update queue changes
- April 23: Dependencies merged
- May 11, 2018: Merged
- Oct 2018: Shipped in 16.6 (code-splitting only)

Enabled React.lazy() for code-splitting but data fetching was still experimental."}

nodes.title: PR #13398: React.lazy - Code Splitting API (Aug 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #13398: React.lazy
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/13398
Author: Andrew Clark (@acdlite)
Created: August 14, 2018
Merged: August 16, 2018

From PR description:
"Lazily starts loading a component the first time it's rendered. The implementation is fairly simple and could be left to userspace, but since this is an important use case, there's value in standardization."

"Final name is TBD. I went with lazy for now because it's short and descriptive."

"I put it on the main React export because it's small and importing this at the top of every file will get old really quickly."

WHY React.lazy was added:
- Before: Code splitting required wrapping components with loadable-components or react-loadable
- These libraries handled loading states manually
- With Suspense, a simpler API was possible
- React.lazy + Suspense = declarative code splitting

Usage:
const OtherComponent = React.lazy(() => import('./OtherComponent'));

<Suspense fallback={<Loading />}>
  <OtherComponent />
</Suspense>

The component lazily loads when first rendered, Suspense handles the loading state."}

nodes.title: PR #13748: React.memo (originally pure) - Function Component Memoization (Sept 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #13748: pure (later renamed to memo via PR #13905)
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/13748
Author: Andrew Clark (@acdlite)
Created: September 27, 2018
Merged: September 27, 2018 (same day!)

RFC discussion: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/63

From PR description:
"A higher-order component version of the React.PureComponent class. During an update, the previous props are compared to the new props. If they are the same, React will skip rendering the component and its children."

"Unlike userspace implementations, pure will not add an additional fiber to the tree."

"The first argument must be a functional component; it does not work with classes."

"pure uses shallow comparison by default, like React.PureComponent. A custom comparison can be passed as the second argument."

WHY React.memo was needed:
- Before: Function components always re-rendered, even if props didn't change
- PureComponent only worked for classes
- Userspace solutions (like recompose's pure()) added an extra fiber node
- React.memo is implemented at the reconciler level - no extra fiber overhead

Renamed to "memo" because:
- "pure" implies purity in the FP sense (same inputs = same outputs)
- Components aren't pure - they can read context, use hooks, etc.
- "memo" more accurately describes what it does: memoization of render output"}

nodes.title: PR #13683: Scheduler Package Created - Extracted Scheduling Logic (Sept 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Scheduler Package Evolution in 16.6

Originally "react-scheduler", renamed to "schedule" (PR #13543, Sept 3, 2018), 
then to "scheduler" (PR #13683, Sept 19, 2018).

Key PR: #13720 - Priority levels, continuations, and wrapped callbacks
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/13720
Author: Andrew Clark (@acdlite)
Created: September 25, 2018
Merged: September 25, 2018

From PR description:
"All of these features are based on features of React's internal scheduler. The eventual goal is to lift as much as possible out of the React internals into the Scheduler package."

Priority Levels (from PR):
- Immediate priority: Fires at the end of the outermost currently executing (similar to a microtask)
- Interactive priority: Fires within a few hundred milliseconds. For quick user feedback
- Normal priority: Default. Fires within several seconds
- "Maybe" priority: Only fires if nothing else to do. For prerendering/warming cache

Continuations:
"Adds the ability for a callback to yield without losing its place in the queue, by returning a continuation. The continuation will have the same expiration as the callback that yielded."

WHY the Scheduler was extracted:
- React's internal scheduling logic was useful beyond just React
- Enabled other libraries to use the same cooperative scheduling
- Allowed browser vendors to potentially adopt/standardize
- Foundation for Concurrent Mode"}

nodes.title: React 16.8 Era - Hooks Ship (Feb 2019)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"React 16.8.0 released February 6, 2019

This release shipped Hooks - the most significant addition to React's programming model since the original class-based API.

RFC: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/68
React Conf 2018 announcement (October 2018)

Key features:
1. useState - state in function components
2. useEffect - lifecycle/side effects in function components
3. useContext - context consumption in function components
4. useReducer - Redux-like state management
5. useCallback, useMemo - memoization hooks
6. useRef - refs in function components
7. useImperativeHandle - customize ref handles
8. useLayoutEffect - synchronous effects
9. useDebugValue - custom hook devtools labels

Also shipped:

Hooks were presented at React Conf 2018 and merged October 29, 2018 behind a flag.
Stable release: February 6, 2019"}

nodes.title: PR #13968: Hooks Implementation (Oct 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #13968: Implement the experimental Hooks proposal behind a feature flag
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/13968
Author: Sebastian Markbåge (@sebmarkbage)
Created: October 25, 2018
Merged: October 29, 2018

From PR description:
"Hooks let you use all React features (such as state and lifecycle) without writing a class."

"We have presented the Hooks proposal at React Conf 2018. This pull request implements all proposed built-in Hooks behind a feature flag, both for the client and the server renderer."

"This is a very early time for Hooks and this proposal is experimental. We're merging it into master now so we can iterate on it. It is turned on only in the 16.7 alpha release so that you can try it and provide your feedback."

"We have been using this code for a month in production so while the APIs are not stable, we don't expect the implementation to contain major bugs."

RFC for discussion: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/68

WHY Hooks were added (from RFC/docs):
1. "It's hard to reuse stateful logic between components" - HOCs and render props cause "wrapper hell"
2. "Complex components become hard to understand" - lifecycle methods mix unrelated logic
3. "Classes confuse both people and machines" - `this` binding, minification issues, hot reloading

Hooks tied deeply into Fiber:
- Hooks list stored on Fiber node (memoizedState)
- Hook state persists across renders via Fiber
- Enables function components to have state without classes"}

nodes.title: Hooks deeply integrate with Fiber - hook state stored on Fiber.memoizedState as linked list
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Hooks are implemented in the reconciler as part of Fiber nodes.

Key reconciler implementation details:

1. Hook State Storage:
   - Each Fiber node has a `memoizedState` field
   - For function components with hooks, this stores a linked list of hook objects
   - Each hook object has: memoizedState, baseState, baseQueue, queue, next

2. Hook Execution Order:
   - Hooks MUST be called in the same order every render
   - The linked list is traversed in order during render
   - This is why hooks can't be called conditionally

3. Dispatcher Pattern:
   - Hooks are called via a "dispatcher" that changes based on phase
   - First render uses HooksDispatcherOnMount
   - Updates use HooksDispatcherOnUpdate
   - Invalid calls (outside render) use a different dispatcher that throws

4. Effect Lists:
   - useEffect/useLayoutEffect create effect objects
   - Effects stored in Fiber.updateQueue
   - Committed in the commit phase (useLayoutEffect sync, useEffect async)

Code location: packages/react-reconciler/src/ReactFiberHooks.js

This design enables function components to have state without class semantics, while fitting into Fiber's interruptible rendering model."}

nodes.title: React 17.0 Era - No New Features, Foundation for Future (Oct 2020)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"React 17.0.0 released October 20, 2020

"No New Features" - A stepping stone release focused on making React easier to upgrade.

Key changes:
1. Event delegation changed from document to React root container
2. New JSX Transform (no need to import React for JSX)
3. Lanes model introduced behind flag (PR #18796)
4. Effect cleanup timing changes
5. Native component stacks in errors
6. Removed event pooling

WHY "No New Features":
- React team wanted to make it easier to upgrade between major versions
- Previous major versions had breaking changes that made gradual upgrades hard
- React 17 allows multiple React versions on the same page (for gradual upgrades)
- Foundation for React 18's Concurrent Features

The Lanes model (PR #18796) was the biggest internal reconciler change, but shipped behind a flag. This replaced the ExpirationTimes model from Fiber."}

nodes.title: PR #18796: Lanes Implementation - Replaces ExpirationTimes (May 2020)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #18796: Initial Lanes implementation
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/18796
Author: Andrew Clark (@acdlite)
Created: May 1, 2020
Merged: May 3, 2020

From PR description - Technical description of Lanes:
"There are two primary advantages of the Lanes model over the Expiration Times model:
- Lanes decouple the concept of task prioritization ('Is task A higher priority than task B?') from task batching ('Is task A part of this group of tasks?').
- Lanes can express many distinct task threads with a single, 32-bit data type."

WHY Lanes replaced ExpirationTimes:
From PR: "This constraint was designed before Suspense was a thing, and it made some sense in that world. When all your work is CPU bound, there's not much reason to work on tasks in any order other than by their priority. But when you introduce tasks that are IO-bound (i.e. Suspense), you can have a scenario where a higher priority IO-bound task blocks a lower-priority CPU-bound task from completing."

"At first by design, but then more by accident, the old model coupled the two concepts of 1) prioritization and 2) batching into a single data type. We were limited in our ability to express one except in terms that affected the other."

Key translation (from PR):
- renderExpirationTime -> renderLanes
- update.expirationTime -> update.lane
- fiber.expirationTime -> fiber.lanes
- fiber.childExpirationTime -> fiber.childLanes

"In the new model, we have decoupled those two concepts. Groups of tasks are instead expressed not as relative numbers, but as bitmasks:
const isTaskIncludedInBatch = (task & batchOfTasks) !== 0;"

This was the foundation for React 18's Concurrent Features - enables parallel UI transitions and better Suspense handling."}

nodes.title: ExpirationTimes model flaw: Could not express IO-bound vs CPU-bound task priorities - high pri IO task could block low pri CPU task
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"From PR #18796 (Lanes implementation):

"In the old model, to decide whether to include a given unit of work in the batch that's being worked on, we would compare their relative priorities:
const isTaskIncludedInBatch = priorityOfTask >= priorityOfBatch;

This worked because of a constraint we imposed where lower priority tasks were not allowed to complete unless higher priority tasks are also included. Given priorities A > B > C, you couldn't work on B without also working on A; nor could you work on C without working on both B and A."

"This constraint was designed before Suspense was a thing, and it made some sense in that world. When all your work is CPU bound, there's not much reason to work on tasks in any order other than by their priority."

The problem with Suspense:
"But when you introduce tasks that are IO-bound (i.e. Suspense), you can have a scenario where a higher priority IO-bound task blocks a lower-priority CPU-bound task from completing."

Additional limitation:
"A similar flaw of Expiration Times is that it's limited in how we can express a group of multiple priority levels. Using a Set object isn't practical, in terms of either memory or computation — the existence checks we're dealing with are extremely pervasive, so they need to be fast and use as little memory as possible."

This architectural limitation was a major blocker for Concurrent Mode and advanced Suspense features."}

nodes.title: Event Delegation Change: Events attached to root instead of document (React 17)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"React 17 changed where event listeners are attached.

Before React 17:
- All event listeners attached to the document
- Single event delegation for the entire page

React 17 and later:
- Event listeners attached to the root container (where ReactDOM.render was called)
- Each React root has its own event delegation

WHY this change was made:

1. Multiple React versions on same page:
   - Enables gradual React upgrades (React 17 tree can coexist with React 16 tree)
   - Each version manages its own events at its own root
   - Events don't interfere between versions

2. Better integration with non-React code:
   - Event listeners on document could interfere with other libraries
   - stopPropagation() now works as expected with non-React event handlers

3. Preparation for React 18's concurrent features:
   - Multiple roots could be rendering concurrently
   - Each root needs isolated event handling

Blog post: https://reactjs.org/blog/2020/08/10/react-v17-rc.html

This was a breaking change but enabled the "gradual upgrades" philosophy of React 17."}

nodes.title: React 17.0.0 Released - Foundation for Concurrent React (Oct 20, 2020)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"React 17.0.0 Released October 20, 2020

"No New Features" Release - but critical foundation work:

2. New JSX Transform - no React import needed

WHY "No New Features" was strategic:

From blog: "The React 17 release is unusual because it doesn't add any new developer-facing features. Instead, this release is primarily focused on making it easier to upgrade React itself."

"In particular, React 17 is a 'stepping stone' release that makes it safer to embed a tree managed by one version of React inside a tree managed by a different version of React."

This enabled:

The Lanes model (PR #18796) shipped behind a flag but was tested at Facebook, preparing for React 18."}

nodes.title: React 18 Era - Concurrent React Ships (March 2022)

"Concurrent React" - The culmination of years of Fiber work.

Breaking Changes:

nodes.title: createRoot/hydrateRoot APIs - Enable Concurrent Rendering (React 18)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"createRoot and hydrateRoot - The Gateway to Concurrent React

From React 18 changelog:
"createRoot: New method to create a root to render or unmount. Use it instead of ReactDOM.render. New features in React 18 don't work without it."

"hydrateRoot: New method to hydrate a server rendered application. Use it instead of ReactDOM.hydrate in conjunction with the new React DOM Server APIs. New features in React 18 don't work without it."

WHY new APIs were required:
- ReactDOM.render used "legacy mode" (synchronous, React 17 behavior)
- createRoot enables "concurrent mode" (interruptible rendering)
- Couldn't change render() behavior without breaking existing apps
- New API provides clear opt-in to concurrent features

Migration:
Before: ReactDOM.render(<App />, container)
After: createRoot(container).render(<App />)

Both APIs accept onRecoverableError option for error logging.

PRs: #10239, #11225, #12117, #13732, #15502, #15532, #17035, #17165, #20669, #20748, #20888, #21072, #21417, #21652, #21687, #23207, #23385

Authors: @acdlite, @bvaughn, @gaearon, @lunaruan, @rickhanlonii, @trueadm, @sebmarkbage

This was the final piece that exposed Fiber's concurrent capabilities to users after 6 years of development."}

nodes.title: useTransition/startTransition - Urgent vs Non-Urgent Updates (React 18)
Automatic Batching - All Updates Batched by Default (React 18)
useSyncExternalStore - Safe External Store Integration (React 18)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"useSyncExternalStore - Solving the "Tearing" Problem

From React 18 changelog:
"useSyncExternalStore is a new hook that allows external stores to support concurrent reads by forcing updates to the store to be synchronous. It removes the need for useEffect when implementing subscriptions to external data sources, and is recommended for any library that integrates with state external to React."

WHY this was critical:
- Concurrent rendering can read state at different points in time
- External stores (Redux, Zustand, etc.) could show inconsistent UI ("tearing")
- Before: Two components might see different values from the same store
- useSyncExternalStore ensures consistent snapshots

The "tearing" problem:
- Component A reads store value = 1
- React yields to browser
- External event changes store value = 2
- Component B reads store value = 2
- UI shows inconsistent state (A=1, B=2)

useSyncExternalStore forces synchronous reads to prevent this.

PRs: #15022, #18000, #18771, #22211, #22292, #22239, #22347, #23150
Authors: @acdlite, @bvaughn, @drarmstr

This hook was essential for Redux 8, Zustand, and other state management libraries to work correctly with Concurrent React."}

nodes.title: React 18.0.0 Released - Concurrent React Ships After 6 Years (March 29, 2022)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"React 18.0.0 Released March 29, 2022

Blog: https://reactjs.org/blog/2022/03/29/react-v18.html
Changelog PR: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/24195

The culmination of 6 years of Fiber development.

Timeline from Fiber to Concurrent React:
- 2016: Fiber work begins (Issue #6170)
- Sept 2017: React 16.0 - Fiber ships (sync only)
- Oct 2018: React 16.6 - Suspense for code splitting
- Feb 2019: React 16.8 - Hooks
- Oct 2020: React 17.0 - Lanes model behind flag
- March 2022: React 18.0 - Concurrent React ships

Key features delivered:
1. createRoot/hydrateRoot - enable concurrent mode
2. useTransition/startTransition - priority scheduling
3. useDeferredValue - deferred rendering
4. useSyncExternalStore - external store integration
5. useId - SSR-safe unique IDs
6. useInsertionEffect - CSS-in-JS
7. Automatic batching
8. Selective hydration
9. Streaming SSR (renderToPipeableStream)

Breaking changes:
- Strict Mode double-invokes effects
- Stricter hydration errors
- Consistent useEffect timing

This release finally delivered on the promise of "async rendering" that was first mentioned in 2016 with Issue #6170."}

nodes.title: PR #28491: useActionState Hook - Actions in React (March 2024)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #28491: Add React.useActionState
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/28491
Author: Ricky (@rickhanlonii)
Created: March 5, 2024
Merged: March 22, 2024

From PR description:
"This PR adds a new React hook called useActionState to replace and improve the ReactDOM useFormState hook."

WHY useActionState over useFormState:
"The useFormState hook is only exported from the ReactDOM package and implies that it is used only for the state of <form> actions... This leads to understandable confusion about why useFormState does not provide a pending state value like useFormStatus does."

"The key insight is that the useFormState hook does not actually return the state of any particular form at all. Instead, it returns the state of the action passed to the hook"

Changes:
- Renames useFormState to useActionState
- Adds a pending state to the returned tuple
- Moves the hook to the 'react' package (renderer agnostic)

Type:
function useActionState<State>(
  action: (state: Awaited<State>) => State | Promise<State>,
  initialState: Awaited<State>,
  permalink?: string,
): [state: Awaited<State>, dispatch: () => void, boolean];

This enables React 19's "Actions" pattern - async functions that integrate with transitions and Suspense."}

nodes.title: PR #28097: Async Actions in startTransition (Jan 2024)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #28097: Async action support for React.startTransition
URL: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/28097
Author: Andrew Clark (@acdlite)
Created: January 25, 2024
Merged: January 26, 2024

From PR description:
"This adds support for async actions to the 'isomorphic' version of startTransition (i.e. the one exported by the 'react' package). Previously, async actions were only supported by the startTransition that is returned from the useTransition hook."

WHY this was important:
"The interesting part about the isomorphic startTransition is that it's not associated with any particular root. It must work with updates to arbitrary roots, or even arbitrary React renderers in the same app. (For example, both React DOM and React Three Fiber.)"

"The idea is that React.startTransition should behave as if every root had an implicit useTransition hook, and you composed together all the startTransitions provided by those hooks."

Key behavior:
- Multiple updates to the same root will be batched together
- Updates to one root will not be batched with updates to other roots
- Features like useOptimistic work the same as with hook version

Difference from hook version:
"an error triggered inside an async action cannot be captured by an error boundary, because it's not associated with any particular part of the tree."

This enabled "Actions" pattern in React 19 - async functions with automatic pending states and optimistic updates."}

nodes.title: PR #8193: Task Priority for Error Boundaries (Nov 2016)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #8193: "Task" priority for error boundaries and batched updates
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/8193
Merged: November 4, 2016
Author: @acdlite

VERBATIM from PR description:
"Introduces a new priority level, Task. (The name is provisional. We'll come up with something better later.)

Task priority is similar to Synchronous priority. Both are flushed in the current tick. The difference is:
- work with the Task priority is performed within the current tick, but at the end of the batch of work (after all work has been committed).
- work with the Synchronous priority is performed immediately. E.g. a synchronous setState will perform all its work before the setState call exits.

In #8127, these two types of work priority were both considered 'synchronous.' Splitting them into separate concepts will make it easier to schedule and batch things correctly.

Currently used for batchedUpdates and nested sync updates. Task should also be used for updates inside componentDidUpdate/Mount, error boundary work, and events."

WHY THIS MATTERS:
This PR established the priority system that would evolve into Lanes. Error boundaries specifically need Task priority because:
1. Error recovery must happen AFTER work is committed, not during
2. Allows proper stack unwinding when errors occur
3. Enables batching of error recovery work
4. Foundation for eventual Error Boundaries API in React 16

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Introduced priority levels beyond just sync/async
- Created foundation for scheduler complexity
- Enabled error boundaries as a first-class Fiber feature"}

nodes.title: PR #8532: Portal Unmounting and Sibling Insertion Fixes (Dec 2016)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #8532: [Fiber] Fix portal bugs
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/8532
Merged: December 12, 2016
Author: @gaearon

VERBATIM from PR description:
"When we unmount a portal, we need to unmount *its* children from itself. This is similar to what we would do for a root if we allowed deleting roots.

A portal is not part of that host tree despite being a child.

If pendingProps is null, we do a bailout in beginWork. This prevents unmounting of the existing child when the new child is null.

We fix this by changing portal fiber's pendingProps to be the portal object itself instead of its children. This way, it is never null, and thus doesn't cause a false positive in the bailout condition."

KEY FIXES:
1. Fix portal unmounting - children must unmount from portal, not parent container
2. Skip portals when looking for host siblings - portals aren't part of host tree
3. Fix null portal child reconciliation - portal props must never be null

WHY THIS MATTERS:
Portals are a critical Fiber feature enabling rendering children into different DOM containers. This PR fixed fundamental bugs in how Fiber tracks portal children and their relationship to the host tree. The fix to use portal object as pendingProps (not children) established a pattern used throughout Fiber's bailout logic.

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Established portal as distinct from host tree traversal
- Fixed child reconciliation for special fiber types
- Pattern: use container object as props to avoid null bailout issues"}

Intentional semantic differences:
In the old implementation, in sync mode, retrying a previously suspended tree is synchronous inside the promise resolution callback. The new implementation schedules an async callback to perform the retry. If multiple promise resolutions occur before the async callback fires, they will be batched together.

2. Enabled batching of multiple promise resolutions
3. Unified the scheduler integration across all React features

nodes.title: PR #16214: Yield Many Times Per Frame - No rAF Approach (Jul 2019)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #16214: [scheduler] Yield many times per frame, no rAF
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/16214
Merged: July 26, 2019
Author: @acdlite

VERBATIM from PR description:
"Adds experimental flag to yield many times per frame using a message event loop, instead of the current approach of guessing the next vsync and yielding at the end of the frame.

This new approach forgoes a requestAnimationFrame entirely. It posts a message event and performs a small amount of work (5ms) before yielding to the browser, regardless of where it might be in the vsync cycle. At the end of the event, if there's work left over, it posts another message event.

This should keep the main thread responsive even for really high frame rates. It also shouldn't matter if the hardware frame rate changes after page load (our current heuristic only detects if the frame rate increases, not decreases).

The main risk is that yielding more often will exacerbate main thread contention with other browser tasks.

I'm also not sure to what extent message events are throttled when the tab is backgrounded, relative to requestAnimationFrame or setTimeout. I'm starting with the assumption that message events fire with at least the same priority as timers, but I'll need to confirm.

Let's try it and see."

WHY THIS MATTERS:
This fundamentally changed how React yields to the browser:
1. Removed dependency on requestAnimationFrame (unreliable for high refresh rate displays)
2. 5ms work chunks ensure consistent responsiveness regardless of display refresh rate
3. More predictable yielding behavior across different devices
4. Essential for concurrent mode to feel smooth

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Changed scheduling from frame-based to time-based
- Established 5ms as the work chunk size (still used today)
- Foundation for scheduler behavior in React 18+"}

nodes.title: How should React yield to browser during rendering?
Option: requestAnimationFrame-based yielding (guess next vsync)
Option: Message event loop with 5ms work chunks (CHOSEN)
rAF REJECTED: Only detects frame rate increases not decreases; guessing vsync unreliable for high refresh rate displays
Message Events CHOSEN: Posts small 5ms work chunks; yields to browser regardless of vsync cycle; responsive even for high frame rates; removes rAF dependency

nodes.title: PR #22644: useId Hook - Stable ID Generation During SSR and Hydration (Nov 2021)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #22644: useId
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/22644
Merged: November 1, 2021
Author: @acdlite

VERBATIM from PR description:
"New hook API that generates stable ids during server rendering and hydration to avoid mismatches.

Outside of server-rendered content, it falls back to a global counter.

This is intended to replace useOpaqueIdentifier.

ID GENERATION ALGORITHM:
Ids are base 32 strings whose binary representation corresponds to the position of a node in a tree.

Every time the tree forks into multiple children, we add additional bits to the left of the sequence that represent the position of the child within the current level of children.

    00101       00010001011010101
    ╰─┬─╯       ╰───────┬───────╯
  Fork 5 of 20       Parent id

The leading 0s are important. In the above example, you only need 3 bits to represent slot 5. However, you need 5 bits to represent all the forks at the current level, so we must account for the empty bits at the end.

It's possible for the size of the sequence to exceed 32 bits, the max size for bitwise operations. When this happens, we make more room by converting the right part of the id to a string and storing it in an overflow variable."

WHY THIS MATTERS:
1. Accessibility: ARIA attributes require stable IDs that match between SSR and client
2. Form labels: for/id connections need deterministic IDs
3. SSR hydration: Random IDs cause hydration mismatches
4. Replaces hacky workarounds like useOpaqueIdentifier

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Added tree position-based ID generation to Fiber
- Uses base-32 encoding for compact IDs
- Handles 32-bit overflow for deep trees
- Integrated with Fiber's context stack for zero-cost after hydration"}

PR #16880: Selective Hydration - Prioritize Interactive Content (Sept 2019)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #16880: Selective Hydration
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/16880
Merged: September 25, 2019
Author: @sebmarkbage

VERBATIM from PR description:
"Because hydration in concurrent mode is yieldy, we can switch hydration priority when new events come in. Selective Hydration gives us the ability to increase priority of roots and suspense boundaries based on what is being interacted with.

Discrete events are replayed in order. They are based an intentional user action so they normally have pretty high priority.

Replaying has some quirks given that we don't know if preventDefault will be called or not. Normally we allow the default behavior. However, a lot of times we'll already have received the data necessary to unblock a boundary. I.e. we're CPU bound.

This PR attempts to first synchronously hydrate the path to the discrete target. Only if that fails, do we create a queue to be replayed later."

WHY THIS MATTERS:
1. Enables partial page interactivity BEFORE full hydration completes
2. User interactions increase priority of hydrating that specific content
3. Discrete events (clicks, etc.) can synchronously hydrate their target path
4. Critical for large apps with slow-loading data dependencies
5. Foundation for React 18's streaming SSR + hydration

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Added ability to prioritize hydration based on user interaction
- Integrated with Fiber's priority system
- Event replay queue for events that arrive before hydration
- Changed hydration from all-or-nothing to incremental"}

nodes.title: PR #20672: Parallel Transitions - Assign Different Lanes to Consecutive Transitions (Feb 2021)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #20672: Parallel transitions: Assign different lanes to consecutive transitions
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/20672
Merged: February 8, 2021
Author: @acdlite

VERBATIM from PR description:
"Currently we always assign the same lane to all transitions. This means if there are two pending transitions at the same time, neither transition can finish until both can finish, even if they affect completely separate parts of the UI.

The new approach is to assign a different lane to each consecutive transition, by shifting the bit to the right each time. When we reach the end of the bit range, we cycle back to the first bit. In practice, this should mean that all transitions get their own dedicated lane, unless we have more pending transitions than lanes, which should be rare.

We retain our existing behavior of assigning the same lane to all transitions within the same event. This is achieved by caching the first lane assigned to a transition, then re-using that one until the next React task, by which point the event must have finished. This preserves the guarantee that all transition updates that result from a single event will be consistent."

WHY THIS MATTERS:
1. Before this: Two transitions blocked each other even if unrelated
2. After this: Independent transitions can complete separately
3. Uses bit-shifting through transition lane range
4. Maintains consistency WITHIN an event (same lane)
5. Allows concurrency BETWEEN events (different lanes)

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Changed lane assignment from static to dynamic for transitions
- Uses bit-shifting to cycle through available transition lanes
- Enables true concurrent UI updates
- Major improvement to React 18's concurrent rendering UX"}

https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/25207
Merged: September 8, 2022
Author: @acdlite

VERBATIM from PR description:
"Follow up to #25084. Implements experimental_use(promise) API in the Server Components runtime (Flight).

The implementation is much simpler than in Fiber because there is no state. Even the 'state' added in this PR — to track the result of each promise across attempts — is reset as soon as a component successfully renders without suspending.

There are also fewer caveats around neglecting to cache a promise because the state of the promises is preserved even if we switch to a different task.

Server Components is the primary runtime where this API is intended to be used.

The last runtime where we need to implement this is the server renderer (Fizz)."

WHY THIS MATTERS:

2. Simpler implementation in Server Components (no persistent state)
3. Avoids Suspense overhead when possible
4. Foundation for React 19's use() API
5. Server Components is the PRIMARY target for this API

RECONCILER IMPACT:

nodes.title: PR #17285: Flight Basic Streaming Suspense Support - RSC Protocol (Nov 2019)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #17285: [Flight] Basic Streaming Suspense Support
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/17285
Merged: November 6, 2019
Author: @sebmarkbage

VERBATIM from PR description:
"This adds basic Suspense support to Flight by streaming the response.

First it sends one line with the root JSON model. Within the model holes are replaced with '$' followed by a hex ID. E.g. '$12AB3'.

Subsequent lines begin with 'J' followed by a hex ID.

So an example response may look something like:
{\"some\":{\"json\":\"$1\"},data:[\"$1\",\"$2\"]}
J1:{\"more\":\"data\"}
J2:{\"even\":\"more\"}

The client suspends if you try to access an unresolved value. Once a new line comes in it unsuspends that part of the model.

ERRORS:
If the server errors while rendering one of the models that error is encoded with an 'E' prefix... When this happens, the previously suspended part of the model now resolves and starts throwing an error on the client.

FUTURE ADDITIONS:
- URL: preload other resources without waiting for JSON parsing
- Blob: binary data support for data viz use cases
- HTML: raw HTML for faster parsing and efficient size"

WHY THIS MATTERS:
1. Defined the RSC (React Server Components) wire protocol
2. $ placeholder pattern for lazy-loading data
3. J (JSON), E (Error) line prefixes
4. Foundation for all React Server Components streaming
5. Error boundaries work across server/client boundary

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Defined streaming protocol for Server Components
- Suspense integration with streaming responses
- Error propagation across network boundary
- Foundation for react-server-dom-webpack, react-server-dom-turbopack"}

nodes.title: PR #12404: getSnapshotBeforeUpdate - New Commit Phase Lifecycle (March 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #12404: New commit phase lifecycle: getSnapshotBeforeUpdate
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/12404
Merged: March 26, 2018
Author: @bvaughn

VERBATIM from PR description:
"Add new 'commit' phase lifecycle, getSnapshotBeforeUpdate, that gets called _before_ mutations are made. Any value returned by this lifecycle will be passed as the third parameter to componentDidUpdate.

This lifecycle is important for async rendering, where there may be delays between 'render' phase lifecycles (e.g. componentWillUpdate and render) and 'commit' phase lifecycles (e.g. componentDidUpdate).

This PR follows the precedent set by getDerivedStateFromProps and _does not call_ unsafe legacy lifecycles componentWillMount, componentWillReceiveProps, or componentWillUpdate for any component that defines the new getSnapshotBeforeUpdate method."

WHY THIS MATTERS:
1. Enables capturing DOM state (scroll position, etc.) BEFORE mutations
2. Async-safe: works correctly with concurrent rendering
3. Part of lifecycle modernization for async React
4. Replaced problematic componentWillUpdate use cases
5. Value passed to componentDidUpdate as third parameter

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Added new lifecycle phase in commit sequence
- Called BEFORE mutations, value passed to componentDidUpdate
- Components using new lifecycle skip unsafe legacy lifecycles"}

nodes.title: PR #12201: Stack Unwinding Phase for Handling Errors - Fiber Error Recovery Rewrite (Feb 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #12201: Add stack unwinding phase for handling errors
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/12201
Merged: February 24, 2018
Author: @acdlite

VERBATIM from PR description:
"A rewrite of error handling, with semantics that more closely match stack unwinding.

Errors that are thrown during the render phase unwind to the nearest error boundary, like before. But rather than synchronously unmount the children before retrying, we restart the failed subtree within the same render phase. The failed children are still unmounted (as if all their keys changed) but without an extra commit.

Known differences from existing error handling semantics in synchronous mode:
- When a component throws an error, we continue rendering its siblings rather than unwind immediately.
- Because of the previous point, a single error boundary may capture more than one error during a single render, if multiple child branches fail.
- We call componentDidCatch for each error that a boundary captures, instead of just the first one.
- Error boundaries only catch error objects. Non-errors will propagate to the root and cause the tree to unmount."

WHY THIS MATTERS:
1. Major rewrite of Fiber error handling
2. Stack unwinding semantics instead of synchronous unmount
3. Enables getDerivedStateFromCatch (later getDerivedStateFromError)
4. Multiple errors can be caught per render
5. Foundation for async-safe error recovery

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Complete rewrite of error handling in Fiber
- Render phase errors unwind without extra commit
- Commit phase errors scheduled on update queue
- Siblings continue rendering after error"}

nodes.title: PR #13746: getDerivedStateFromError - Render Phase Error Recovery (Sept 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #13746: Enable getDerivedStateFromError
https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/13746
Merged: September 28, 2018
Author: @bvaughn

VERBATIM from PR description:
"Commits are split up for easier review:
- Remove the enableGetDerivedStateFromCatch feature flag
- Copy-paste ReactErrorBoundaries to ReactLegacyErrorBoundaries to preserve tests for legacy componentDidCatch recovery behavior
- Update previous ReactErrorBoundaries tests to cover new getDerivedStateFromCatch render-phase behavior
- Rename getDerivedStateFromCatch to getDerivedStateFromError
- Add DEV warning if an error boundary specifies only the componentDidCatch lifecycle and does not trigger a state update (because this would swallow the error)"

WHY THIS MATTERS:
1. Enables render-phase error recovery (no extra commit needed)
2. Static method - async-safe unlike componentDidCatch
3. Can derive state from error before retry render
4. Renamed from getDerivedStateFromCatch for clarity
5. Part of React 16.6 release

RECONCILER IMPACT:
- Added static getDerivedStateFromError lifecycle
- Called during render phase (not commit phase)
- Allows retry without extra commit
- Works alongside componentDidCatch for logging"}
