PR #12745: Add Profiler Component for Collecting Render Time Metrics (May 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"PR #12745: Add Profiler component for collecting new time metrics

From PR description by Brian Vaughn (bvaughn):
"Add a new component type, Profiler, that can be used to collect new render time metrics. Since this is a new, experimental API, it will be exported as React.unstable_Profiler initially.

The onRender callback is called each time the root renders. It receives:
- id: string - The id value of the Profiler tag
- phase: string - Either 'mount' or 'update'
- actualTime: number - Time spent rendering the Profiler and its descendants
- baseTime: number - Duration of the most recent render time for each individual component

'Actual' render time: Time spent rendering the Profiler and its descendants for the most recent render/update. Paused (and accumulated) for scheduling/timing interruptions. Paused (and accumulated) for aborted renders (e.g. suspense).

'Base' render time: Duration of the most recent render time for each individual component within the Profiler tree. Times are not updated/recorded if a component skips render because of shouldComponentUpdate."

WHY: React needed built-in performance measurement that understood its own scheduling, interruptions, and memoization. Browser dev tools couldn't distinguish between work React did vs work React skipped due to shouldComponentUpdate."}

nodes.title: PR #10783: Add Fragment as Named Export to React (Oct 2017)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #10783: Add Fragment as a named export to React

From PR description by Clement Hoang (clemmy):
"This PR is a part of the bigger change to introduce <></> fragment syntax to JSX. With this named export, we'll be able to de-sugar <></> into React.createElement(React.Fragment) calls.

We want to align fragment with array behavior:
- top level keyed React.Fragment => create fragment fiber
- top level un-keyed React.Fragment => no fragment fiber created  
- nested fragments => fragment fiber created
- React.Children will treat fragments as a terminal element

You can think of it as the quantum theory of fragments. It has both array-like and element-like properties."

WHY: Before Fragments, returning multiple elements from render required wrapping in a div or using array syntax with keys. Fragments allowed grouping children without adding extra DOM nodes. The design balanced array-like behavior (no fiber overhead for simple cases) with element-like behavior (proper keying and nesting)."}

nodes.title: PR #14853: Async act() for Testing Async Updates (Apr 2019)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"PR #14853: await act(async () => ...)

From PR description by Sunil Pai (threepointone):
"You've seen the synchronous version - act(() => { // updates }). This still works. But if you pass an async function:

await act(async() => {
  // updates and stuff
})
// expect commits and effects to be flushed

I set it up so if you *don't* await the result from act, a warning gets triggered (with setImmediate) to do so.

Pros:
- works with async/await, solves oss problems cleanly
- the sync api is preserved  
- the warning is preserved
- works with fake timers/fb

Cons:
- can't guarantee batching after the first await in an act block (this will get better when concurrent?)
- less restrictive than the sync model"

WHY: Testing async React updates (suspense, data fetching, effects) was painful. act() wraps testing code to ensure updates are flushed and assertions run after React has finished processing. The async version extends this to promise-based workflows while maintaining the same flush-before-assert guarantee."}

nodes.title: PR #16432: Babel Transform JSX to React.jsx/React.jsxDEV (Aug 2019)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #16432: Babel Transform JSX to React.jsx/React.jsxDEV Plugin

From PR description:
"As per the RFC to simplify element creation, we want to change the JSX transform from targeting React.createElement(type, props, children) to React.jsx(type, props, key).

The main differences between React.jsx/React.jsxDEV and React.createElement are:
1) key is now passed as an explicit argument rather than through props
3) children are now passed through props rather than as an explicit argument
4) props must always be an object
5) __source and __self are now passed as separate arguments into React.jsxDEV rather than through props

Part of the rationale for this change is that we want to deprecate key spread through props because this is an expensive dynamic comparison operation. We want users instead always explicitly pass key as a prop."

WHY: React.createElement had accumulated legacy baggage - key extraction from props required runtime object iteration, and children as varargs was inefficient. The new transform is simpler, faster, and sets up deprecating anti-patterns like spreading key. This was foundational for React 17's "no import needed" JSX improvement."}

nodes.title: PR #28348: Pass ref as Normal Prop - Removes Need for forwardRef (Feb 2024)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #28348: Pass ref as normal prop

From PR description by Andrew Clark (acdlite):
"Changes the behavior of the JSX runtime to pass through ref as a normal prop, rather than plucking it from the props object and storing on the element.

This is a breaking change since it changes the type of the receiving component. However, most code is unaffected since it's unlikely that a component would have attempted to access a ref prop, since it was not possible to get a reference to one.

forwardRef will still pluck ref from the props object, though, since it's extremely common for users to spread the props object onto the inner component and pass ref as a differently named prop. This is for maximum compatibility with existing code — the real impact of this change is that forwardRef is no longer required.

Currently, refs are resolved during child reconciliation and stored on the fiber. As a result of this change, we can move ref resolution to happen only much later, and only for components that actually use them."

WHY: forwardRef was ergonomic friction. Wrapping components to forward refs was tedious and added indirection. With ref as a normal prop, functional components can just accept ref like any other prop. This also enables future optimization - refs can be resolved lazily rather than eagerly during reconciliation."}

nodes.title: PR #26722: Implement useFormStatus - Read Ancestor Form Status (Apr 2023)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"PR #26722: Implement experimental_useFormStatus

From PR description:
"This hook reads the status of its ancestor form component, if it exists.

const {pending, data, action, method} = useFormStatus();

It can be used to implement a loading indicator, for example. You can think of it as a shortcut for implementing a loading state with the useTransition hook.

Internally it's implemented using startTransition + a context object. That's a good way to think about its behavior, but the actual implementation details may change in the future.

Because form elements cannot be nested, the implementation in the reconciler does not bother to keep track of multiple nested 'transition providers'."

WHY: Forms are a primitive interaction pattern. useFormStatus provides declarative access to form submission state without needing to manually wire up loading indicators. Combined with Server Actions, this enables progressive enhancement - forms work without JS, and React enhances them when available."}

PR #11818: New Context API - React.createContext (Jan 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #11818: New context API

From PR description by Andrew Clark (acdlite):
"Introduces a declarative context API that propagates updates even when shouldComponentUpdate returns false.

Corresponding RFC: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/2

We'll land this behind a feature flag and try it out on a Facebook product to get some real-world performance data. My plan is to build the React Redux API on top of it, find our largest product that uses Redux, swap out the implementation, and see what happens.

TODO:
- Should be able to stop scanning when we hit a matching provider, then continue the scan later
- Unwind context stack when interrupted (error, high pri update)
- SSR"

WHY: The old context API was broken - updates wouldn't propagate through shouldComponentUpdate false boundaries, making it unreliable for libraries like Redux. The new API with Provider/Consumer pattern guarantees updates propagate, and integrates with Fiber's interruptible rendering by properly unwinding context stacks."}

nodes.title: StrictMode Double Invocation: Functions passed to useState, useMemo, useReducer are double-invoked in dev to detect side effects in render
PR #13748: React.memo (originally React.pure) - Functional PureComponent (Sept 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #13748: React.pure (renamed to React.memo)

From PR description by Andrew Clark (acdlite):
"A higher-order component version of the React.PureComponent class. During an update, the previous props are compared to the new props. If they are the same, React will skip rendering the component and its children.

Unlike userspace implementations, pure will not add an additional fiber to the tree.

The first argument must be a functional component; it does not work with classes.

pure uses shallow comparison by default, like React.PureComponent. A custom comparison can be passed as the second argument."

RFC: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/63

WHY: Functional components lacked the shouldComponentUpdate optimization that class components had via PureComponent. React.memo fills this gap without requiring class syntax. Unlike HOC solutions, it doesn't add an extra fiber node - the memoized component IS the fiber, making it zero-overhead."}

nodes.title: PR #13398: React.lazy - Lazy Component Loading (Aug 2018)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"PR #13398: React.lazy

From PR description by Andrew Clark (acdlite):
"Lazily starts loading a component the first time it's rendered. The implementation is fairly simple and could be left to userspace, but since this is an important use case, there's value in standardization.

Final name is TBD. I went with lazy for now because it's short and descriptive.

I put it on the main React export because it's small and importing this at the top of every file will get old really quickly."

WHY: Code-splitting was essential for large apps but the ergonomics were terrible - every lazy-loaded boundary required boilerplate. React.lazy standardizes the pattern and integrates with Suspense for seamless loading states. It removes the need for third-party solutions like react-loadable."}

nodes.title: PR #15902: Add SuspenseList Component - Coordinate Loading Sequences (June 2019)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #15902: Add SuspenseList Component

From PR description by Sebastian Markbage (sebmarkbage):
"This component lets you coordinate the loading sequence of nested Suspense boundaries. How this happens is defined by the revealOrder property. By default, it behaves like a noop.

This first PR implements the 'together' option which ensures that all boundaries resolve together. If any of them trigger a fallback, they all do.

The mechanism for this mode is that we do a full render pass first, and then scan the result to see if there are any fallbacks. If there are, we do a full second render pass (including re-reconciliation).

The second pass currently deletes all work that we did in the first pass so it's quite inefficient but this particular mode is expected to be rare and not have large subtrees. We're Suspended anyway."

WHY: Lists of data-loading components create a staggered "popping in" effect as items load at different times. SuspenseList coordinates loading sequences - together (all at once), forwards (top-to-bottom), or backwards (bottom-to-top) - for a polished UX. This was essential for skeleton UI patterns."}

PR #21913: Add useInsertionEffect - CSS-in-JS Injection Before DOM Mutations (Sept 2021)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #21913: [Experimental] Add useInsertionEffect

From PR description:
"Adds back the experimental useMutationEffect hook as useInsertionEffect, initially intended for stylesheet libraries.

This hook is called right before mutations are made to the host, to allow inserting dependencies of the soon-to-be mutated host nodes. The canonical example use case is for inserting styles into the DOM so that they're available before reading layout information from DOM nodes that they apply to (like reading height in useLayoutEffect).

Since this hook is limited in scope, this hook does not have access to refs and cannot schedule updates.

The lifecycle of this hook is a little different than other hooks. useInsertionEffect will interleave create and destroy while traversing the tree in the beforeMutation phase."

WHY: CSS-in-JS libraries (Emotion, styled-components) needed to inject styles before layout effects ran, otherwise layout measurements would be wrong. useInsertionEffect provides a guaranteed-before-layout-effects timing slot specifically for style injection, solving the race condition."}

Float - Resource Hints and Document Metadata (React 18.3+)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Float - Resource Hints and Document Metadata

Float is React's system for managing resources that "float" to the document head - stylesheets, scripts, link elements, and metadata. It provides imperative APIs (preload, preinit, preconnect, prefetchDNS) and declarative rendering of head elements.

Key PRs:
- PR #26237: preconnect and prefetchDNS
- PR #27220: preloadModule and preinitModule  
- PR #26880: fetchpriority support
- PR #26106: Model Float on Hoistables semantics

WHY: Before Float, managing document metadata required escape hatches like react-helmet. Server rendering couldn't coordinate resource hints with component rendering. Float integrates resource management into React's lifecycle - resources are declared where data is fetched, hoisted automatically to the document head, deduplicated, and coordinated with Suspense boundaries."}

PR #28512: Add Diffs to Hydration Warnings (March 2024)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"PR #28512: Add Diffs to Hydration Warnings

From PR description by Sebastian Markbage:
"This builds on the mechanism by adding a diff of everything we've collected so far to the thrown error or logged error.

This isn't actually a longest common subsequence diff. This means that there are certain cases that can appear confusing such as a node being added/removed when it really would've appeared later in the list.

I also present abstract components in the stack, these are presented with the client props and no diff since we don't have the props that were on the server. The lack of difference might be confusing but it's useful for context."

WHY: Hydration mismatches were notoriously hard to debug - you'd get a generic error with no indication of what differed. This PR adds actual diffs showing the server vs client content, making hydration debugging dramatically easier. Combined with component stacks, you can now trace exactly where mismatches occur."}

nodes.title: React Compiler (Forget) - Automatic Memoization at Build Time
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"React Compiler (formerly React Forget) - Automatic Memoization at Build Time

React Compiler is a build-time tool that automatically adds memoization to React components. It analyzes your code and inserts useMemo and useCallback equivalents where beneficial.

Key aspects:
- Compiles at build time, not runtime
- Analyzes data flow to determine what needs memoization
- Preserves React's mental model - you write normal React code
- Validates against rules of React (no side effects in render, etc.)
- Ships with React 19 as experimental

WHY: Manual memoization (useMemo, useCallback, React.memo) is error-prone and tedious. Developers either over-memoize (wasting memory) or under-memoize (missing optimizations). React Compiler applies memoization optimally based on actual data dependencies, removing the need for manual optimization while ensuring correctness."}

nodes.title: Issue #7925: Fiber Umbrella - Bugs Found During Rewrite
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Issue #7925: [Fiber] Umbrella for remaining features / bugs

This GitHub issue tracked ALL the bugs discovered during the Fiber rewrite. It documents the painful reality of rewriting a core system - hundreds of edge cases and subtle bugs.

Key bug categories discovered:
1. **DOM node lifecycle bugs**: findDOMNode returning stale nodes in unmount
2. **Deletion tracking bugs**: Switching element types didn't properly track what to delete
3. **Refs bugs**: Refs not updating when shouldComponentUpdate returned false  
4. **Scheduling bugs**: setState in componentDidMount not batching correctly
5. **Context bugs**: Push/pop stack not properly matched during interruption
6. **Event bugs**: Event listeners becoming stale when work is interrupted
7. **Reentrant mounting bugs**: Complex race conditions when mounting triggers more mounts

WHY THIS MATTERS: Each of these bugs represents a behavioral contract that React had with developers that needed to be preserved. The Fiber rewrite couldn't just be "faster" - it had to be bug-for-bug compatible with Stack in synchronous mode while enabling new async capabilities."}

nodes.title: BUG: findDOMNode broken when used in componentWillUnmount - Fiber could return stale node (PR #8897)
BUG: Switching between element types didn't track deletions - updateSlot didn't return null (PR #8085)
BUG: Refs wouldn't update if shouldComponentUpdate returned false (PR #8685)
BUG: setState in componentDidMount scheduled async instead of sync at batch end (PR #8206)
BUG: Context push/pop wasn't properly matched - caused tests to fail (PR #8568)
Issue #8830: Async Rendering Umbrella - Fundamental Model Flaws
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Issue #8830: [Umbrella] Async rendering - Fundamental Model Flaws

From the issue description by Andrew Clark (acdlite):
"Async rendering is incomplete. There are bugs with the existing implementation and crucial features that are missing.

The bugs are related to resuming work after it has been interrupted.

PR #9695 was an effort to clean up the bugs without fundamentally changing the underlying model. In the course of working on that branch, we've decided that the underlying model is inherently flawed and needs to change.

The tricky case is when low priority work is interrupted by a higher priority update. We want to be able to reconcile again at the higher priority without losing the low priority children, so that we can resume them later. There's no way to do this with the existing model.

So we're going to scrap the model and start again."

WHY THIS MATTERS: This is a rare admission that the React team had to throw away their first async implementation. The original priority-based model fundamentally couldn't handle interruption without losing work. This led to the expiration time model and eventually Lanes."}

nodes.title: CRITICAL BUG: Low priority work interrupted by high priority lost children - couldn't resume without re-reconciling everything (PR #9695)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"CRITICAL BUG: Work loss during priority interruption

When high priority work interrupted low priority work, React couldn't resume without re-reconciling everything. The children of interrupted work were lost.

From Issue #8830: "The tricky case is when low priority work is interrupted by a higher priority update. We want to be able to reconcile again at the higher priority without losing the low priority children, so that we can resume them later. There's no way to do this with the existing model."

This wasn't a minor edge case - it was the entire async rendering proposition. If you couldn't interrupt and resume, async rendering was pointless.

The fix required a complete redesign: scrap the "progressed work" model, implement expiration times, and later evolve to the Lanes model."}

nodes.title: BUG: Priority starvation - low priority work could be starved indefinitely by continuous high priority updates
How to solve priority starvation in async rendering?
Option: Use fixed priority levels (REJECTED - causes starvation)
Option: Use expiration times - work expires and must be flushed (CHOSEN)

OLD MODEL: Effects tracked via linked list (firstEffect → nextEffect chain) - required traversing entire tree to find effects
PROBLEM: Linked list traversal O(n) for commit phase; couldn't skip subtrees without effects; complex pointer management
PR #19673: Remove effect list - Switch to subtreeFlags bitmask bubbled up during render (Oct 2020)
NEW MODEL: subtreeFlags bitmask on each fiber bubbled during completeWork - O(1) check if subtree has effects; enables skipping entire subtrees
BUG #23111: Safari ignores setState when iframe added to DOM in same commit - microtask timing difference in Safari
PR #20890: Lazily propagate context changes - Only mark dirty consumers, don't eagerly propagate (Dec 2020)
flushSync: Escape hatch to force synchronous update - bypasses batching but can cause tearing and performance issues if misused
CORE INSIGHT: React's power comes from treating rendering as a pure function of state - Fiber enabled making this interruptible without breaking the abstraction
WHY 6 YEARS (2016-2022): Each architectural solution revealed new edge cases only visible at scale - tearing, starvation, dropped updates, infinite loops - requiring multiple iterations

INSPIRATION: Dan Abramov's 'Algebraic Effects for the Rest of Us' explains how Fiber's design mirrors algebraic effects - ability to 'pause' computation, do something else, and 'resume' - without actually using effect handlers
